text: Folks, serious question: what CMS do you use to match both marketing and dev demands? specifically, would be handy to hear from those of you using a headless CMS or one that's built in-house/proprietary? thanks! :pray:

elements.text: Folks, serious question: what CMS do you use to match both marketing and dev demands? specifically, would be handy to hear from those of you using a headless CMS or one that's built in-house/proprietary? thanks!

text: <@UJG24P8P6> can tell you more but Prismic is pretty good when it comes to a headless CMS for content.

elements.text: can tell you more but Prismic is pretty good when it comes to a headless CMS for content.

text: Does anyone have experience with using video/image advertisement optimization tools such as Marpipe, Trypencil, Smartly, Vidmob or other tools? I have a few questions. Would be great to connect. Thanks

elements.text: Does anyone have experience with using video/image advertisement optimization tools such as Marpipe, Trypencil, Smartly, Vidmob or other tools? I have a few questions. Would be great to connect. Thanks

text: At Ghost we use our own headless CMS. If you have any specific technical questions I'd be happy to pass them along

elements.text: At Ghost we use our own headless CMS. If you have any specific technical questions I'd be happy to pass them along

text: I second what <@U012GHRAHDK> said - Prismic’s not bad

elements.text: I second what
said - Prismic’s not bad

text: We use Prismic for the blog and the marketing site (<http://friday.app|friday.app>) Performance-wise, it's been really great and is easier than WP to copy & paste for blog posts. The search functions for an expanding library aren't great. You also need to have a dev/front-end person to help you make any changes. There aren't a bunch of plug-ins like WP

elements.text: We use Prismic for the blog and the marketing site (friday.app) Performance-wise, it's been really great and is easier than WP to copy & paste for blog posts. The search functions for an expanding library aren't great. You also need to have a dev/front-end person to help you make any changes. There aren't a bunch of plug-ins like WP

text: <@U012GHRAHDK> <@U02681WABA7> <@UJG24P8P6> How did you manage page-level controls for SEO? Meta content and directives, sitemap inclusion/exclusion, OG fields, etc.? My experience is that Prismic doesn't ship with this control built into the interface - it needs to be extended with dev resources.

elements.text: How did you manage page-level controls for SEO? Meta content and directives, sitemap inclusion/exclusion, OG fields, etc.? My experience is that Prismic doesn't ship with this control built into the interface - it needs to be extended with dev resources.

text: <@U02FNEQ3E5A> I asked a front-end dev responsible for the Prismic integration to add these page-level controls :eyes: He just asked me which options I wanted included, and it didn’t take him much time to implement.

elements.text: I asked a front-end dev responsible for the Prismic integration to add these page-level controls
He just asked me which options I wanted included, and it didn’t take him much time to implement.

text: I work at a software dev/design agency and we almost always recommend Wagtail to clients for it's flexibility for both dev teams and content editing

elements.text: I work at a software dev/design agency and we almost always recommend Wagtail to clients for it's flexibility for both dev teams and content editing

text: <@U02FNEQ3E5A> Prismic has "slices" and the front-end/dev person can build those out

elements.text: Prismic has "slices" and the front-end/dev person can build those out

text: <@U012GHRAHDK> "Make your website editable for the whole team" good stuff!

elements.text: "Make your website editable for the whole team" good stuff!

text: <@U02FNEQ3E5A> In terms of page control, seems like Prismic works similarly to Ghost as you'd still have to get your devs on board first

elements.text: In terms of page control, seems like Prismic works similarly to Ghost as you'd still have to get your devs on board first

text: <@U019P0ADPCH> :thumbsup: And good to know about Ghost, too — haven't looked into that. <@UJG24P8P6> All clear, thanks.

elements.text: And good to know about Ghost, too — haven't looked into that.

text: Anyone have any recommendations for an SEO keyword generators? I get ads for Yoast through my website all the time, but I have done just old school research for clients. Looking to automate and optimize this task better. Thanks!

elements.text: Anyone have any recommendations for an SEO keyword generators? I get ads for Yoast through my website all the time, but I have done just old school research for clients. Looking to automate and optimize this task better. Thanks!

text:
What's your goal with a keyword generator?

I'd totally skip Yoast. That plugin doesn't do anything measurable for SEO (and typically really hurts the content with their recommendations).

elements.text:
What's your goal with a keyword generator?

I'd totally skip Yoast. That plugin doesn't do anything measurable for SEO (and typically really hurts the content with their recommendations).

text: Simplify the SEO task process for myself ultimately.

elements.text: Simplify the SEO task process for myself ultimately.

elements.text: SEO Surfer

text: Are you looking to do keyword research to inform a content strategy?

elements.text: Are you looking to do keyword research to inform a content strategy?

text:
SEO should never lead a content strategy :slightly_smiling_face:

_(Not saying you said that, but just in case anybody reading things a strategy should start with an SEO tool)_

elements.text: SEO should never lead a content strategy
(Not saying you said that, but just in case anybody reading things a strategy should start with an SEO tool)

text: Agree with Brendan here. I keep seeing less and less power surrounding "keywords" and more emphasis on audience resonance and interesting perspectives. IMO, your best "keyword generator" is Googling the topic you want to rank for and studying the SERPs to see what's ranking.

elements.text: Agree with Brendan here. I keep seeing less and less power surrounding "keywords" and more emphasis on audience resonance and interesting perspectives. IMO, your best "keyword generator" is Googling the topic you want to rank for and studying the SERPs to see what's ranking.

text: Second to that, you can use Google autocomplete suggestions and people also ask as strong indicators of related topics that folks are likely to care about

elements.text: Second to that, you can use Google autocomplete suggestions and people also ask as strong indicators of related topics that folks are likely to care about
